citation.article-title: Emended descriptions of Clostridium acetobutylicum and Clostridium beijerinckii, and descriptions of Clostridium saccharoperbutylacetonicum sp. nov. and Clostridium saccharobutylicum sp. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Emended description of Clostridium acetobutylicum McCoy et al. 1926

The description of Clostridium acetobutylicum in Bergey's Manual of Systematic Bacteriology (Cato et al., 1986) is based on the description by Smith & Hobbs (1974) and Holdeman et al. (1977). Smith & Hobbs (1974) group this species within Group II of the genus Clostridium, on the basis of its ability to hydrolyse gelatin. However, Holdeman et al. (1977) describe this species as being unable to hydrolyse gelatin, as in Bergey's Manual.We found that all seven representative strains of C. acetobutylicum tested positive for gelatin liquefaction. This is in agreement not only with the formal description of C. acetobutylicum by McCoy et al. (1926), but also with the description given in the patent, issued to Weizmann (1919), describing the original acetone-butanol fermentation process. The description of C. acetobutylicum should therefore be emended accordingly. Furthermore, we found that amygdalin and raffinose were fermented by C. acetobutylicum. This is contrary to the description given in Bergey's Manual but is in agreement with the formal description given by McCoy et al. (1926). In addition, we found that C. acetobutylicum was able to ferment saccharose and pectin but was able to ferment turanose only weakly.
